title: Allow users to configure HTTP header fuzzing in API Fuzzing
description:
### Problem to solve

As a user I want to selectively enable fuzzing of HTTP headers with the option to include or exclude specific headers.

Many web APIs use headers (custom and well defined) to track API version, perform authentication/authorization, etc. Because this headers are read by the application code, vulnerabilities may exist in them.

Some common web frameworks such as Java's Spring, produce server errors (500) when headers are tested, even when no actual issue has been found. For this reason it's useful to start with this option disabled and allow selective use.

API Fuzzing already has the ability to test HTTP headers, however it was disabled in 13.3 to provide a better default experience. This issue will re-introduce the feature with the ability to configure it on a per-check basis.

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### User experience goal

User can configure header testing via the API Fuzzing yaml configuration file.

### Proposal

Configure header testing via new configuration options for General Fuzzing Check. Fuzzing `headers` can be a source of false positives, so the option will default to off and require listing each header to be fuzzed.

* General Fuzzing Check is the only check active for headers
* Provide the following options:
  * On/Off
  * Included headers list
* Default to off

The following checks will have this configuration option:

* General Fuzzing Check

Document this portion of the configuration file.

<!-- ### Further details -->

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Documentation

Add documentation on this new configuration option.

### Availability & Testing

* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Users ability to enable/disable header fuzzing via the configuration file.

<!-- ### Links / references -->

### Technical Solution

1. [x] Make changes to check
1. [x] Write integration test
1. [x] Update production configuration file with new configuration settings set to off
1. [x] Write documentation
1. [x] Publish analyzer

title: Add unique users importing groups to usage ping (Import GMAU)
description:
## Problem
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/manage/general-discussion/-/issues/17232, we described the need for a Group MAU for Import. This should be a measure of the number of unique users taking an action that is important to the goals of the group.

## Proposal
* Add the number of unique users importing groups to usage ping.
* This number will count all attempted imports (not successful completion).
* Since the number of distinct importers (actions) is large, this feature will be implemented in multiple issues
* Following (group) importers are **in scope for this issue**:
  * GitLab Group importer (API and UI)

title: [FE] Define a segment in DevOps Report
description:
## Problem
One of the most important aspects of the feature proposed in https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4169 is the ability to create custom segments. These could be a subset of members working on a monorepo, or a series of multiple projects that are managed and built by a particular team.

## Proposal

| Empty state | Modal | Table | Tooltips & dropdown menu | Toast |
| ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ |
| ![Empty_state](/uploads/c06996e8ed9420ba0b6da1968941a8d5/Empty_state.png) | ![Modal](/uploads/12ca88c3edd0d310bdb8a45e1d57d5d1/Modal.png) | ![Table](/uploads/fae061c244e252dd552859416d24ee0a/Table.png) | ![Tooltips___dropdown_menu](/uploads/3e4f7c85a0070338b78c40643fc47907/Tooltips___dropdown_menu.png) | ![Toast](/uploads/52587eab9116f2315e55a5b4863b7f91/Toast.png) |

Create a "Segments" button on the DevOps Report page. This should expose a modal that allows me to create a new segment. Confirm submission with toast message "Segment created".

This is the ~frontend portion.
~backend issue is https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/262395

Scope of this iteration:
1. Page in admin section (will later be moved to instance-level)
   - Newly created segments should appear on the DevOps Report page.
1. Empty state
1. Modal to define segments (top-level groups only in first iteration)
   - Constraint handling: Constrain segments to contain 20 max groups only (top-level)
1. Add segment button
   - Disable and add tooltip when table rows = 30.
1. Add segment row to table
   - Number of segments in table (max): 30
1. Confirmation toast when new segment is created

Later iterations:
- Edit segment
- Delete segment

### Questions
If we update the data overnight, what should we do with an immediately created segment?

title: DAST Scanner Profiles implementation - Form MVC - Edit profiles - Frontend
description:
* Main issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/222767
* Parent issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235407
* ~backend counterpart: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235408

## Summary

This issue is for adding edit capability to the **DAST Scanner Profile** form.

## Implementation plan

### Production code

- [ ] Create the `DastSiteProfilesController#edit` controller action in `ee/app/controllers/projects/dast_scanner_profiles_controller.rb`.
  - [ ] The action should retrieve the profile being edited and pass it down to the view.
- [ ] Create the corresponding `edit` route in `ee/config/routes/project.rb`.
  - [ ] The route should be protected with the same policy as `/:namespace/:project/-/on_demand_scans`.
- [ ] Create the HAML view in `ee/app/views/projects/dast_scanner_profiles/edit.html.haml`.
  - [ ] The HAML view renders a mount point for the previously created **DAST Scanner Profile** form.
  - [ ] It passes the profile's data down to the Vue app via `data-` attributes:
    - [ ] ID.
    - [ ] Profile Name.
    - [ ] Spider Timeout.
    - [ ] Target Timeout.
- [ ] Active nav items for editing profile
  - [ ] In ee/app/helpers/ee/projects_helper.rb
- [ ] Create the client-side GraphQL mutation `dastScannerProfileUpdate` in `ee/app/assets/javascripts/dast_scanner_profiles_form/graphql/dast_scanner_profile_update.mutation.graphql`
- [ ] Implement the edit mode in the **DAST Scanner Profile** form.
  - [ ] The component should accept a profile's data via props (see `data-` attributes above).
  - [ ] The fields should be populated with the profile's data.
  - [ ] On submit, the `dastScannerProfileUpdate` mutation is triggered instead of `dastScannerProfileCreated`, and the variables include the profile's ID.
  - [ ] Strings match the edit context.
    - [ ] Title.
    - [ ] Generic error message.
    - [ ] Cancel modal title.
- [ ] Add `#scanner-profile` to the redirect link for form submission & discard

### Specs

- [ ] `ee/spec/frontend/dast_scanner_profiles_form/components/dast_scanner_profiles_form_spec.js`
  - [ ] Shows correct strings depending on the `new`/`edit` context.
  - [ ] Handles submission success properly
    - [ ] Loading state.
    - [ ] GraphQL mutation.
    - [ ] Redirection.
  - [ ] Handles submission errors properly
    - [ ] Loading state.
    - [ ] Generic error.
    - [ ] Erros-as-data.
  - [ ] Cancellation
    - [ ] Form untouched.
      - [ ] Redirection.
    - [ ] Form touched.
      - [ ] Confirmation
      - [ ] Redirection.
* [ ] `ee/spec/views/projects/dast_scanner_profiles/new.html.haml_spec.rb`
  * [ ] Share `new` action's specs.

## Related resources

* Prior work: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38315

title: Add timestamps for when vulnerabilities are found in API Fuzzing reports
description:
### Problem to solve

The DAST team is adding a timestamp to the vulnerability section of the report. API Fuzzing will also need to make this change.

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/214298 for a full description of the problem being solved and what changes are resulting in the schema.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Proposal

Update API Fuzzing's scanner to capture the timestamp of new findings and include them in the generated vulnerability report. This work is blocked by the schema updates being made by the DAST team, and adding vulnerability report support to API Fuzzing.

### Further details

This will help our intended users reduce pipeline run times without sacrificing proper security hygiene. This will also help us internally by giving us metrics on what we can set for sane default values for how long scans should run.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Each vulnerability instance has a timestamp included with it.

### Links / references

DAST Issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/214298#note_372770360

### Technical Solution

This feature will be implemented by adding a new field `DiscoveredAt` to the `Fault` model.

1. [x] Add `DiscoveredAt` field to:
   1. [x] `Fault` model
   1. [ ] `FaultDetailBase`
   1. [ ] Interfaces as needed
1. [x] Add new data migration, adding new field to db
1. [ ] Regenerate default SQLite database with new field
1. [x] Set timestamp when creating a new Fault
1. [x] Add unit test to verify timestamp is set
1. [x] Update security report generation to include new field (if this code is already written).
1. [x] Write a test to validate security report contains timestamp that matches Finding

title: When license is expired Git push error is nil
description:
When a customer's license has expired there are certain circumstances which can lead to the [`Gitlab::ExpiringSubscriptionMessage`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/cd36b8c8ca8f96eac4a44fa92b6cc746aed2f3cc/ee/lib/gitlab/expiring_subscription_message.rb) being `nil`. This is the message passed back to the Git client as part of the `Gitlab::GitAccess::ForbiddenError`. When the message is `nil`, the only error the client sees is the exception class itself. 

There are dozens of places where GitLab raises `Gitlab::GitAccess::ForbiddenError`. @cody, @dstanley and I debugged this issue with a customer in a call. It was extremely difficult to find the root cause since the error message was nil/generic. 

We ultimately tracked it down to a blocked push because the license was expired. The license had expired on January 18, 2020. They thought they had uploaded a new license but did not. 

- License is checked as part of [`check_change_access!`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/cd36b8c8ca8f96eac4a44fa92b6cc746aed2f3cc/ee/lib/ee/gitlab/git_access.rb#L105-108).
- The [`license_message`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/cd36b8c8ca8f96eac4a44fa92b6cc746aed2f3cc/ee/app/helpers/ee/subscribable_banner_helper.rb#L26) is generated from [`Gitlab::ExpiringSubscriptionMessage`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/cd36b8c8ca8f96eac4a44fa92b6cc746aed2f3cc/ee/lib/gitlab/expiring_subscription_message.rb). 

The piece here that is confusing is how much logic goes into the very first line of the [`Gitlab::ExpiringSubscriptionMessage#message`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/cd36b8c8ca8f96eac4a44fa92b6cc746aed2f3cc/ee/lib/gitlab/expiring_subscription_message.rb#L20) method. No matter what the case, for an expired license, we should show some message when we block a push. 

Maybe the disconnect happens because this class is also used to decide whether we display a banner to users/admins in the UI. But we also didn't see a banner in the UI when signed in as an admin, either. So I think this is a bug affecting both pushes and the lack of banner in the UI when the license is expired.


## Reported Examples

1. https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/171723
1. https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/197572
1.

title: Support Group Milestones to be associated with Project Releases in API
description:
### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

Release managers working across multiple projects in GitLab often use Group Milestones to collect related items for a scheduled a release. You may have realized that GitLab Releases could be associated to a Project Milestone before and now you can associate a Group Milestone to a Project Release via the Releases API. This will be a great help to all the Release Managers coordinating their releases with milestones. 

<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a breakdown of [Support release association to group milestones (Edit release page)](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/121476), we'll need to modify the [releases API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/releases/) to allow for submissions that `GET`, `POST`, `UPDATE`, and `DELETE` group milestones to be associated with a release. This will probably require creating a new `group_milestone` attribute and will likely need to be done after https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235387

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->
 Only group milestones that belong to the project's immediate group can be added to the existing `milestones` array, milestones belonging to any of the project's ancestor groups cannot be added. There is existing validation in place that ensures there is not a naming clash between project and project's group milestones.

The signature if the of the release API call does not hange, and the groups could be added to the same array, ie:

```json
curl --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --request PUT --data '{"name": "milestone release", "milestones": ["release-milestone-1","subgroup-milestone"]}' --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN: <redacted>" "http://127.0.0.1:3000/api/v4/projects/20/releases/v25" | jq
```

Where **release-milestone-1** is the project milestone, and **subgroup-milestone** is the group milestone.


### Links / references
This is connected to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235387, where we will make the association in the database. 

This is Iteration 1 of 
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/121476

title: Search text color is unreadable in Web IDE using the Monokai theme
description:

When using the Monokai theme, the text in the search box does not have enough contrast and is unreadable.

title: SAST Custom Rules - Passthrough Scanner Configuration
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

To complete [Custom Rulesets for SAST Analyzers](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4179) we should provide the ability to passthrough a configuration block to the underlying scanners.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 


### Proposal

1. Update `analyzers/common` to detect and parse `.gitlab/sast-rules.toml`
1. If configuration file is present, analyzer provides a compatible customization hook ([similar to our `plugin.go` architecture](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/blob/master/plugin/plugin.go)), and `[[ANALYZER.passthrough]]` is present, provide analyzer-specific configuration `file` to underlying tool (gosec-only initially)
1. Check for `GITLAB_PLAN` [as defined in licensing issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235374) using [`os.GetEnv`](https://golang.org/src/os/env.go?s=2860:2890#L91)

```toml
[gosec]
  description = 'gosec custom rules configuration'

  [[passthrough]]
    type = file
    source/target/destination = gosec-config.json
    value = gosec-config.json
```

### Further details

The initial usecase is to reach feature parity with the previously introduced [`SAST_GOSEC_CONFIG`](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html#analyzer-settings) functionality of the [`gosec` analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec). By instead providing a method of supplying the configuration through [our SAST rules configuration file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229579#links-references) instead of directly via an ENV.

This reframes our customization functionality around a single customization entrypoint and provides the basic framework within `common` and our analyzers to build on top of.

### Permissions and Security

No change to permissions

### Documentation

- Update [Static Application Security Testing docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html) with new section on configuration file
- [optionally] Consider deprecating `SAST_GOSEC_CONFIG`

### Availability & Testing

- Add unit tests to `analyzers/common` covering new customization architecture
- Add downstream test to `analyzers/gosec` where configuration file is specified to modify default behavior (similar to [`gosec-config-FREEZE` branch](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/blob/6358c2cf956f4efe9ec5790c53aab7504d7c313c/.gitlab-ci.yml#L25))

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Customers have clear location for modifying analyzer behaviors

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

No, only ~"group::static analysis" 

### Links / references

title: SAST  & Secret-Detection Custom Rules - Modifying Pre-existing Rules - Overriding Properties
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

To complete [Custom Rulesets for SAST Analyzers](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4179) we should provide the ability to modify specific rules for our individual ~"Category:SAST" and ~"Category:Secret Detection" analyzers, allowing overrides of properties.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 
* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)

### User experience goal

Better data quality for users in better aligning rule properties with organization expectations.

### Proposal

- Update [SAST rules configuration file specification](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229579#links-references) to allow individual rules values to be overridden; i.e. `severity = High`. These rules must match the primary identifier [as defined by a given analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/blob/6358c2cf956f4efe9ec5790c53aab7504d7c313c/convert.go#L197-201) (Perhaps `Value`?)
  - Allowlist of override-able attributes: `name`, `message`, `description`, `severity`, ~`confidence`~
- Validate supported override values
- Update [`analyzers/command/run.go`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/ad4512e178763acd1d3214e64045bdfd0a69a8be/command/run.go#L148-150) to override any returned findings with values specified in configuration file

Update analyzers to enable modifying preexisting rules 
- [x] [brakeman](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/brakeman#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [phpcs-security-audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/phpcs-security-audit#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [security-code-scan](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/security-code-scan#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [bandit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [eslint](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/eslint#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [mobSF](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/mobsf)
- [x] [flawfinder](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/flawfinder#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [gosec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [sobelow](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/sobelow#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [semgrep](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/semgrep#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner) 
- [x] [kubesec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kubesec#kubesec-analyzer)
- [x] [kics](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kics/)
- [x] [nodejs-scan](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/nodejs-scan#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [secrets](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [pmd-apex](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/pmd-apex#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)
- [x] [spotbugs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs#how-to-update-the-upstream-scanner)

#### Example

```toml
[spotbugs]
  [[spotbugs.ruleset]]
    # Properties I'm overriding below
    severity = "Low"
    description = "Predictable random number generator detected, but I don't really care because this is a PoC to demonstrate crackable password hashes"
    # Filter on identifier
    [spotbugs.ruleset.identifier]
    type = "find_sec_bugs_type" # not needed but for readability
    value = "PREDICTABLE_RANDOM"
```

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Permissions and Security

No change to permissions

### Documentation

- Document functionality within [Static Application Security Testing docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html)
- Document functionality within [Secret Detection Testing docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/secret_detection)

### Availability & Testing

- Add test ensuring overridden rule generates findings matching the override value

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Rules can be disabled if considered insignificant to users

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

<!-- Communicate if this change will affect multiple Stage Groups or product areas. We recommend always start with the assumption that a feature request will have an impact into another Group. Loop in the most relevant PM and Product Designer from that Group to provide strategic support to help align the Group's broader plan and vision, as well as to avoid UX and technical debt. https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/#cross-stage-features -->

title: SAST Custom Rules - Disabling Pre-existing Rules
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

To complete [Custom Rulesets for SAST Analyzers](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4179) we should provide the ability to disable specific rules for our individual ~"Category:SAST" analyzers.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 
* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)

### User experience goal

Lower signal-to-noise ratio for security rules that one's team does not consider significant.

### Proposal

#### Implementation Plan

1. Update [SAST rules configuration file specification](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229579#links-references) to allow individual rules to be set as `disable = true`. These rules must match the any identifier [as defined by a given analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/blob/6358c2cf956f4efe9ec5790c53aab7504d7c313c/convert.go#L197-201) using predefined filter attributes (such as `identifier.type` and `identifier.value`)
1. Update [`analyzers/command/run.go`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/ad4512e178763acd1d3214e64045bdfd0a69a8be/command/run.go#L148-150) to filter out disabled rules
1. Check `GITLAB_PLAN` for rule disablement
1. Document functionality within [Static Application Security Testing docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/47847

Update SAST analyzers common version and add `report.Analyzer`/`report.Config.Path`
- [x] gosec https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/merge_requests/79
- [x] nodejs-scan https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/nodejs-scan/-/merge_requests/83
- [x] secrets https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/merge_requests/86
- [x] pmd-apex https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/pmd-apex/-/merge_requests/47
- [x] spotbugs https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs/-/merge_requests/79
- [x] sobelow https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/sobelow/-/merge_requests/44
- [x] security-code-scan https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/security-code-scan/-/merge_requests/58
- [x] brakeman https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/brakeman/-/merge_requests/50
- [x] bandit https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit/-/merge_requests/59
- [x] flawfinder https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/flawfinder/-/merge_requests/44
- [x] phpcs-security-audit https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/phpcs-security-audit/-/merge_requests/46
- [x] eslint https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/eslint/-/merge_requests/62
- [x] mobSF https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/mobsf/-/merge_requests/9
- [x] kubesec https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kubesec/-/merge_requests/39


Future iterations may handle this more efficiently by disabling rules for the analyzer execution itself (don't even try to find rules that are disabled) but we can consider this optimization later.

#### Example

```toml
[spotbugs]
  [[spotbugs.ruleset]]
    # Properties to filter on
    [spotbugs.ruleset.identifier]
    type = "find_sec_bugs_type" # not needed but for readability
    value = "PREDICTABLE_RANDOM"

    disable = true
```

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Permissions and Security

No change to permissions

### Documentation

~~Document functionality within [Static Application Security Testing docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html)~~

Done with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/47847/diffs

### Availability & Testing

- Add test ensuring disabled rule does not yield findings in generated reports

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Rules can be disabled if considered insignificant to users

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

<!-- Communicate if this change will affect multiple Stage Groups or product areas. We recommend always start with the assumption that a feature request will have an impact into another Group. Loop in the most relevant PM and Product Designer from that Group to provide strategic support to help align the Group's broader plan and vision, as well as to avoid UX and technical debt. https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/#cross-stage-features -->

### Links / references

### Release Notes
Building off the success of our previously released [Custom rulesets](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/#custom-rulesets), we are now enabling customers to disable existing default rule sets. This allows organizations to disable rules they wish to ignore or find generate too many false positive results.

title: Add a link to Test Report documentation when no test reports are uploaded
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

If I don't already export/upload test reports in a junit format as part of my pipeline I see an empty test report tab on the pipeline page.

![Tests tab without tests](/uploads/b17f13caa38db3f1dc7b547510fc306e/Screen_Shot_2020-08-10_at_10.50.31_AM.png)

As a developer who has tests in their pipeline, I want to get started quickly with the Test summary and test report features, so that I can quickly diagnose test failures in the Gitlab UI.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer) - who sees 0 reported on the test tab but knows tests are output from their pipeline.
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer) - who gets reports about this 0 showing up but isn't sure how to get the team's test reports into the gitlab UI.

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

The user should be able to get to the JUnit report documentation from an empty test tab with 1 click.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Add a link to the JUnit report documentation to the message about 0 tests.

Something like "There are no tests to show. Learn about how to upload test reports to see how tests are changing and the full report of tests run in a pipeline. [Read the JUnit Report Documentation.](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/junit_test_reports.html)"

### Technical proposal

- Add the documentation link to [the empty state section of the test reports component](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/93d77316b5d03f06fd6e38f7dceb577b2df9977b/app/assets/javascripts/pipelines/components/test_reports/test_reports.vue#L89). We'll have to conditionally show this link if there is no test report, but show the current message if we just have an empty report.
- Add a data attribute for saying whether the pipeline has a test report [in the HAML file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/3ec5c3e11ab1716216aa1acfd80e465a38cb6cb8/app/views/projects/pipelines/_with_tabs.html.haml#L84)
- We should probably also not fetch the test report summary if we already know the pipeline doesn't have a test report. We can do that [by not running `fetchSummary` in the test reports component](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/93d77316b5d03f06fd6e38f7dceb577b2df9977b/app/assets/javascripts/pipelines/components/test_reports/test_reports.vue#L28).
- We'll need to update [the test reports component spec file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/fa456fe2971aa0b66091c08c71cc9dbe571763ab/spec/frontend/pipelines/test_reports/test_reports_spec.js#L0-1) to test this scenario.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

This is a simplified version of the messaging on the DAG pipeline that is being used to drive awareness of that feature.

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?
Consider adding checkboxes and expectations of users with certain levels of membership https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html
* [ ] Add expected impact to members with no access (0)
* [ ] Add expected impact to Guest (10) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members 
* [ ] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Owner (50) members -->

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html#for-a-product-change

* Add all known Documentation Requirements in this section. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

#### Acceptance Criteria
* If no reports are uploaded the messaging appears.
* If an empty report is uploaded do what is done today.
* If a report is uploaded with data to parse do what is done today.

#### Success Measures
* We will review page views of the JUnit docs page 90 days after release of this feature and expect a 10% increase in page views.

<!-- Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this. -->

### What is the type of buyer?

This is for the Individual Developer who can setup their own pipeline OR can influence the decision to output test data in the JUnit format.

In which enterprise tier should this feature go? See https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#four-tiers -->

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

No.

SHELL"}:Hash
description:
https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/1745690/?referrer=gitlab_plugin

```
NoMethodError: undefined method `strip' for {:value=>":NetBackup/\n\n", :name=>"crontab\nSHELL"}:Hash
  wikicloth/wiki_buffer/var.rb:54:in `block in to_html'
    ret = default_functions(function_name,params.collect { |p| p.strip })

    @buffers[-1].data += tmp.send("to_#{@options[:output]}")
  wikicloth.rb:138:in `add_current_char'
    buffer.add_char(c)
...
(119 additional frame(s) were not displayed)

NoMethodError: undefined method `strip' for {:value=>":NetBackup/\n\n", :name=>"crontab\nSHELL"}:Hash
```

## Investigation Notes

Looks like it's a shared concern for ~"group::knowledge" and ~"group::source code"  code, and the bug needs to be fixed in the upstream `wikicloth` gem (which we pull in through our `gitlab-markup` gem).

It only affects files with .wiki suffixes which are parsed as MediaWiki markup. However, I also can't reproduce the error.

This appears to be due to the way params are being handled in the WikiCloth gem. It is unclear if this has to do with functions, or if this is related to something else. In any case, sentry logs make it clear there are several pages we could ask users to view, if that is something we can do (I would be hesitant to bother users, but this may help resolve any issues they are having).

## Potential MR Breakdown

- bugfix in wikicloth
- version bump in gitlab-markup
- version bump in gitlab

title: ActiveRecord::QueryCanceled exceptions in Sentry does not contain timed-out SQL queries
description:
### Summary

We are seeing large amount of issues in Sentry that are related to `ActiveRecord::QueryCanceled` error, but does not contain SQL query that has timed-out. To be able to solve the problem and possibly optimize queries developers has to be able to recognize quickly what happened and provide the fix.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Go to https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/?query=is%3Aunresolved+QueryCanceled
2. Take a look at the list and pick one of the issue, ie. https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/1726305/?query=is%3Aunresolved%20QueryCanceled
3. Take a look at the details of the issue, it does not contain any information about the query.

It used to work (example: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/-/issues/50359)

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Issues related to Database timeout does not contain SQL queries.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Issues related to Database timeout should contain SQL query that timed-out. SQL queries are sanitized and do not contain sensitive data. 

https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C8HG8D9MY/p1595026366230900?thread_ts=1594964842.227200&cid=C8HG8D9MY
> We could potentially look at doing something for both logging and exceptions, where we filter certain types of data using regex (e.g. strings in SQL that are beside = or in IN etc). I saw something recently in the codebase for scrubbing the error content before sending it to frontend errors unless it had a prefix; maybe we could do something like that

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com


### Possible fixes

(If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem)

### Implementation plan

- [ ] Modify `Gitlab::ErrorTracking::process_exception` method to send `sql` information to sentry for all `ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid` errors.
  - [ ] Do not include bind vars into payload
  - [ ] Remove all the values from predicates by using one of the following; https://github.com/tenderlove/gda, https://github.com/cryodex/sql-parser or https://github.com/lfittl/pg_query.

title: Programmatically enforce scanner version in Secure analyzers
description:
### Problem to solve

Now that [Security report provide Scanner version, not Analyzer version](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233448) has been completed, Secure analyzers will output a `scan.scanner.version` value which provides the version number of the underlying `scanner` tool used by the analyzer. We already have a [`check analyzer version`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/628e9b2d0516e4b071a4560fab8c11b9055e84b4/includes-dev/analyzer.yml#L94-113) job which ensures that the **analyzer version** matches the most recent version from the `CHANGELOG.md` file, however, we don't have any way of ensuring that the **scanner version** included in the `scan.scanner.version` field of the secure report matches the one in the `Dockerfile`.

The purpose of this issue is to figure out how to ensure that these two values are the same, to prevent the upstream scanner from being updated without also updating the version in the `scan.scanner.version` value

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

The version of the scanner from the `Dockerfile` must match the version in the `scan.scanner.version` field of the `secure report`.

### Proposal

Replace the following environment variables with a `SCANNER_VERSION` environment variable, and reference this using `os.Getenv("SCANNER_VERSION")` in the [ScannerVersion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/blob/2989dcb338ebe2c4ce6e1fc5cad05156911af56e/metadata/metadata.go#L35) variable of the `metadata.go` file for each of the following projects:

- [x] SAST
   - [x] [security-code-scan](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/security-code-scan/-/blob/c5c196c5cb2a77b9f1c66fd31de44390160d349b/Dockerfile#L4)
      ```
      ENV SECURITY_CODE_SCAN_VERSION ${SECURITY_CODE_SCAN_VERSION:-3.5.3}
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/security-code-scan/-/merge_requests/57
   - [x] [flawfinder](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/flawfinder/-/blob/0a8eb5c42f47e0e8654124c1ea9639feba319a8f/Dockerfile#L3)
      ```
      ARG FLAWFINDER_VERSION=2.0.11
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/flawfinder/-/merge_requests/42
   - [x] [brakeman](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/brakeman/-/blob/7eed617c4b70988abaf2e6fcea62d4095f8f22d2/Dockerfile#L5)
      ```
      RUN gem install brakeman -v 4.9.1
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/brakeman/-/merge_requests/47
   - [x] [spotbugs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs/-/blob/5c0242f1b942586ac0d2645a27a460bdd8dd9699/Dockerfile#L19)
      ```
      ENV SPOTBUGS_VERSION ${SPOTBUGS_VERSION:-4.1.2}
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs/-/merge_requests/76
   - [x] [gosec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/blob/027f08f567d124eada107f35113491e329d49b22/Dockerfile#L3)
      ```
      ARG GOSEC_VERSION=2.4.0
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/merge_requests/77
   - [x] [bandit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit/-/blob/5dc7fb55285d232616e6a6b629e3150641ea8a90/Dockerfile#L11)
      ```
      ARG BANDIT_VERSION=1.6.2
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit/-/merge_requests/56
   - [x] [phpcs-security-audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/phpcs-security-audit/-/blob/fde4bc524b8433766e12fc684a1c22e65eaa699e/Dockerfile#L18)
      ```
      RUN composer require --dev pheromone/phpcs-security-audit 2.0.1
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/phpcs-security-audit/-/merge_requests/45
   - [x] [sobelow](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/sobelow/-/blob/4230885765316971e716b7c6da3fda2f181ce4d8/Dockerfile#L11)
      ```
      ARG SOBELOW_VERSION=0.10.4
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/sobelow/-/merge_requests/43
   - [x] [pmd-apex](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/pmd-apex/-/blob/6c202faa2037eb8c8d1f68d992e349e3eeb45b1d/Dockerfile#L14)
      ```
      ENV PMD_VERSION ${PMD_VERSION:-6.27.0}
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/pmd-apex/-/merge_requests/46
   - [x] [secrets](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/blob/ea887515a84e99a7bdb26bc582337829fb0dabe1/Dockerfile#L11)
      ```
      ENV GITLEAKS_VERSION ${GITLEAKS_VERSION:-v6.1.2}
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/merge_requests/81
   - [x] [eslint](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/eslint/-/blob/79b9b52bedafb451c2ef8041a5d17278e84169a5/package.json#L25)
      `eslint` version is defined in the [package.json](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/eslint/-/blob/79b9b52bedafb451c2ef8041a5d17278e84169a5/package.json#L25) file. See the discussion [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235059#note_415630640) on how to handle this.
      ```
      "eslint": "7.9.0",
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/eslint/-/merge_requests/57
   - [x] [kubesec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kubesec/-/blob/52a86615d9f2cd8829766fb2abdd26a72466d388/Dockerfile#L15)
      `kubesec` version is defined as a git SHA instead of the tag version, since the kubesec Docker container is [tagged with the git SHA](https://hub.docker.com/r/kubesec/kubesec/tags). See the discussion [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235059#note_415659437) on how to handle this.
      ```
      FROM kubesec/kubesec:da10552
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kubesec/-/merge_requests/38
   - [x] ~~[nodejs-scan](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/nodejs-scan/-/blob/146ae838193405eb0c489485876918c2af73f797/Dockerfile#L8)~~
      The `nodejs` version is defined as a git SHA. This will not be implemented because the `nodejs-scan` analyzer will be rewritten, as explained [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235059#note_415634523).
      ```
      ENV NODEJS_SCAN_VERSION=${NODEJS_SCAN_VERSION:-657c60f6582cc8e489e5ba2a183a00c8c5617317}
      ```
- [x] Dependency Scanning
   - [x] [bundler-audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit/-/blob/57e2b7b2041a5bc412606380784ba4372f0ff35e/Dockerfile#L6)
      ```
      ARG BUNDLER_AUDIT_VERSION="0.7.0.1"
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit/-/merge_requests/55
   - [x] [retire.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js/-/blob/28621e9f91bde982f11796477a93ffe3367d5bc3/Dockerfile#L4)
      ```
      ENV RETIRE_JS_VERSION ${RETIRE_JS_VERSION:-2.2.1
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js/-/merge_requests/53
   - [x] [gemnasium-python](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/-/blob/f0dbac9b764b8adb41d7f14d58e113f84b7fc84f/metadata/metadata.go#L30)
      Analyzer and scanner version are the same, no change necessary
   - [x] [gemnasium-maven](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/blob/9872e53b884c3fff6e5b420518d69516f2b89480/metadata/metadata.go#L30)
      Analyzer and scanner version are the same, no change necessary
   - [x] [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/75efc0937360956728e3885b55c9cc92b5353ee4/metadata/metadata.go#L34)
      Analyzer and scanner version are the same, no change necessary
- [x] Container Scanning
   - [x] [klar](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/blob/2989dcb338ebe2c4ce6e1fc5cad05156911af56e/Dockerfile#L15)
      ```
      ARG CLAIR_REPO_TAG=v2.1.4
      ```
      https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/merge_requests/65

### Further details

We need a way to programmatically enforce that the version of the scanner in the `Dockerfile` is the same one as output by the `scan.scanner.version` field in the `secure report`, since adding a rule to the `README` is not sustainable - eventually someone will forget to update this value. We need this process to be automated to prevent making a mistake.

### Availability & Testing

Ensure that it's not possible to have a mismatch of versions between the scanner version specified in the `Dockerfile` and the one reported by `scan.scanner.version`

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

A mismatched version will cause an error, or it simply isn't possible to have mismatched versions

### What is the type of buyer?

~"Enterprise Edition" ~"GitLab Ultimate"

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

Yes, this affects all secure analyzers

### Links / references

See [this discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/merge_requests/62#note_392238093) for more details

/cc @gonzoyumo @NicoleSchwartz

title: Automatically link created issue to vulnerability
description:
When a user clicks the `Create Issue` button, the created issue should automatically show up in the `related issues` box on the vulnerability.

## Designs

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/9424/designs/b3-created-issue-only.png

## Implementation
- [ ] ~frontend automatically link the created issue to the vulnerability by calling the link function in the successful response of the issue creation request (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vulnerabilities/components/header.vue#L177)

Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/9424/

title: Design: Display vulnerabilities by age in security dashboards
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

Today we show trend data about vulnerabilities by severity, which is great for helping users understand how their project(s) are performing historically. Next, to further enhance the dashboard experience, we should show users vulnerabilities by age. This will allow teams to identify vulnerabilities that may be slipping past their SLAs.  

### Intended users

* Security Directors
* Security Managers
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### User experience goal

**When** I am managing vulnerabilities for my organization, **I want** to quickly identify remediations that are slipping, **so I can** take escalation action and avoid missing an SLA or worse, have my organization breached.

### Proposal

Add a [stacked column chart](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/charts-stacked-column-chart--with-zoom-and-scroll) that allows users to visualize the age-range of a vulnerability based on conventional time buckets. 

### Further details

Start with adding this chart to the Project Security Dashboard, then the Instance, and finally Group.

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?
Consider adding checkboxes and expectations of users with certain levels of membership https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html
* [ ] Add expected impact to members with no access (0)
* [ ] Add expected impact to Guest (10) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members 
* [ ] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Owner (50) members -->

### Documentation

### Availability & Testing

title: Geo: Spike skeleton of Repository Strategy for Snippets
description:
Lay a foundation for replicating Repositories so it's clear where code should be, so we can parallelize the rest of the Epic work.

On a call with @vsizov about https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38688, we settled on some rough big ideas:

- We need a `ReplicatoryStrategy` and a `ModelStrategy` for Blobs. These modules are naturally highly coupled. Maybe let's put both modules in one file. Same for Repositories.
- Don't try too hard to hide where/how event publishing is triggered, because every developer adding a `Replicator` class should consider "Do I need to trigger an event somewhere specific to this Model"?
- Let's get the code organization done in 13.3 without necessarily making any replication work.
- Consider breaking out some small initial refactor MRs.
- It should have no effect with the feature flag off
- It should not blow up with the feature flag on
- After this, the Epic will be like a checklist (in some cases, just verifying that something works)

title: POC: Add member management as a deniable policy
description:
## Overview

In https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4168, we're introducing a new policies framework to conditionally deny access to certain behaviors on a per-project basis. In regulated environments, the addition or removal of users to a project or group must follow an approval process and be documented. Other organizations want to spread the load and allow more users to manage group and project membership.

## Proposal

Work on a POC to add project member management as an action that can be defined in a project Policy. During the POC, engineering will evaluate approaches to extend our current permission model to allow denying for specific actions. This model will ideally pave the way for fully custom roles in the future without introducing too much technical debt. We don't have to worry about UX for now but please consider the designs in  https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/280534 and leave feedback there if anything discovered is incompatible.

Relevant background information:
* [Research proposal](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/ux-research/-/issues/62)
* [Prototype allowing limited set of custom roles](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/5626)
* [Project-level policy framework for deny epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4168)

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

**What risks does this change pose to our availability?**

This is low risk to GitLab.com availability. However, one risk I see is the member management feature being (unintentionally) disabled for users that currently have them such as the project owners and admins resulting lockout of this feature.

**What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed?***
- If the deniable policy is assigned to a user, they should not be able to add/remove user to the project from the UI as well as the API
- On GitLab.com, the deniable policy should not be applicable to owner users.
- If the user that has the deniable policy applied in a project is also part of another project in the same parent group, the deniable policy should not affect the user's ability to perform that action in the other project.

title: [UX] Implement open text field for free signup role question when other is selected
description:
### Problem 
Currently, our second most popular selection at signup for the `Role` question is `Other` which leaves us in the dark about what type of user is signing up for GitLab ([source](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/551863/Growth-Conversion-Team:-SamA-Scratch-Dashboard?widget=9422831&udv=949690)).
  
| User experience | Supporting data |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/803cf7eaf5c8df3fe66964ae6c9cae53/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/528537c498555c585d4b92f4af88b6ff/image.png) |
 
### Solution
For one week, we implement a conditional open text field whereby if a signup selects a value of `Other` in the `Role` question we display a free text field for them to provide us with their role. This field should be optional, we should only run this test for a week or two as this will hurt the completion rate of the form since we're introducing another question in the form. However, we can utilize the results to understand if there are more appropriate options we should be including in the role question moving forward. We will turn the experiment off once we feel like we have a sufficient number of responses to update the picklist. 
 
This data should be stored on the backend in the equivalent area where we're already storing the role data as an additional field titled `role-other`.

### Proposed solution

![additional-field](/uploads/a7519e1108ded0bd80fd4c8ea1a1c5fc/additional-field.gif)

#### [Design specs](https://www.figma.com/file/7x9B11kesCFIQzKiYe9ATo/Contextual-input-field-for-roles-in-registration-process?node-id=15%3A0)

epic.title: Use text field to capture further details of Other role type during signup

title: Fuzz testing maturity scorecards
description:
As part of updating our category maturity, we need to go through a [Category Maturity Scorecard](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/category-maturity-scorecards/). We don't need one for Minimal, but will for Viable, Complete, and Lovable maturity.

I wanted to start a discussion in this issue about it so we are set up to do the scorecard when we want to move to Viable at the beginning of 2021.

#### JTBD and stories for material scorecard
The two stories we are going to test for this CMS are bold in this [doc](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1X7BRbSYX_QcWUutlqquOf1umpVMu3f-hGI33SQe0Kk0/edit#gid=0). In case the doc gets updated, the two stories are (current as of 2020-09-25):
1. `When I decided to implement coverage-guide fuzz testing, I want to set it up correctly, so it runs properly agains the code base.`
1. `When I decide to focus on one coverage-guided fuzz result, I want to resolve it properly, so that this finding is not threaten my application anymore.`

#### Target Users



## What needs to be done
* [x] Define Stories(smaller Job To Be Done) that we will test against
* [x] Define Tasks per stories that we will test against
* [x] Define Features for different tasks 
* [x] Define who our users are for the scorecard
* [x] Create research stories with script/recruiting, like the general solution validation process

title: Optimize `EnvironmentSerializer` for N+1 Problem in `environments.json` and `folder.json`
description:
## Problem

It seems `environments.json` has bunch of N+1 issues.

![screenshot_123](/uploads/eb99d60cd6049e199b0d94f6175be2b9/screenshot_123.png)

We can see the following repeated database queries, for example:

- `SELECT 1 AS one FROM ((SELECT "clusters".* FROM "clusters" INNER JOIN "cluster_projects" ON "clusters"."id" = "cluster_projects"."cluster_id" WHERE`
- `SELECT "projects".* FROM "projects" WHERE "projects"."id" = 278964 LIMIT 1`
- `ELECT "namespaces".* FROM "namespaces" WHERE "namespaces"."id" = 9970`

In fact, we aren't preloading associations in the code.

## Query frequencies

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/environments.json

Total: 216 queries

```
     18 "SELECT "routes".* FROM "routes" WHERE "routes"."source_id" = 9970 AND "routes"."source_type" = 'Namespace' LIMIT 1"
     18 "SELECT "namespaces".* FROM "namespaces" WHERE "namespaces"."id" = 9970 LIMIT 1"
     10 "SELECT "routes".* FROM "routes" WHERE "routes"."source_id" = 278964 AND "routes"."source_type" = 'Project' LIMIT 1"
     10 "SELECT "projects".* FROM "projects" WHERE "projects"."id" = 278964 LIMIT 1"
      9 "SELECT "users".* FROM "users" WHERE "users"."id" = 2324599 LIMIT 1"
```

title: Advanced Search Background Migrations for Elasticsearch Indexing
description:
## Problem

At some point we will need to do a migration to our Elasticsearch index that is more than just reindexing within a cluster. For example when we want to add epics to the index https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/4745 or any other issue that may require us to start indexing something new about a document.

For now this issue will serve as a place to brainstorm ideas about this and link up to previous discussions and ideas.

## Solutions

### Original plan for multi version support

Originally we planned to introduce multi version support using an approach that was fully reliant on GitLab to manage both indexes, reading from the old one and writing to both until the migration finished. Some more information at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/18254 and https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/1769 . As at writing this (%"13.3") most of the code still exists for this in GitLab in a half implemented form.

The 2 primary concerns I had with this approach were:

1. Reindexing was done on the GitLab side and it involved reading every single document from the database and sending it to Elasticsearch again. At the rate we index things this will likely take weeks compared to our current in cluster reindexing which can finish in under 24 hrs and can arbitrarily be made faster by scaling up the cluster before the operation.
2. Reindexing everything from GitLab to the cluster again may be very wasteful on occasions where you only need to change a small part of the index. For example if we want to add epics to the index it is very wasteful to reindex every document in the index when we could very quickly just index all the epics. There are many situations where we will be trying to perform some migration that can be done more efficiently using a targeted approach (eg. adding a new field to a document type only requires reindexing all the documents that actually have that field). The implementation we had was very generic and as such we couldn't write very custom migrations that did the least amount of work possible but instead we just relied on reindexing everything from scratch for any change.
3. The actual implementation itself writes to both indexes at the same time which means one slow index will block indexing and if we are reindexing to a new cluster it may be under very high load which will slow down the incremental indexing as well since they are coupled. This could have probably been fixed by refactoring the code a little but it was another part that still needed to be improved.

### Directory of migrations, migrations are workers

I believe that we should do our best to take inspiration from rails DB migrations for whatever solutions we come up with. There are many things to be learnt from these that we don't want to have to learn again.

As such I can imagine a simple approach might be to have a directory of workers. Those workers are numbered like rails migrations and get executed in order. The completion of a worker is persisted in the Elasticsearch cluster. A periodic sidekiq worker is looking for new workers in this directory that haven't yet run. These worker names should start with a timestamp like DB migrations to ensure they are run in order.

We might be tempted to persist the migrations that have run in Postgres. This may not be perfect for the situation where a user wants to connect up a new ES cluster to GitLab. It's probably better to persist the migrations themselves in the ES cluster itself so it's more likely to be in sync.

One problem I can think of is that a job may not be appropriate for a very long migration. We would likely want to spawn many smaller sidekiq jobs from a migration. Perhaps we can use a "Poison Pill" approach in which we queue up a bunch of jobs that are to be executed in sequence (1 at a time) and then add one last job after all of those which is the job which signifies the migration is complete and is the one which then writes to the completed migrations index in Elasticsearch.

Sometimes a migration will need to involve actually triggering a reindex of the ES cluster. Since we may need to reindex the cluster before adding some new data. This could probably still make use of the existing reindex feature in GitLab. The sidekiq worker might just kick off the reindexing and keep requeueing itself until the reindex is completed and then it would persist the fact that the reindex is completed.

A sidekiq migration may also be just triggering something that runs on the ES cluster and watching until it completes. For example an in-cluster reindex might make use of `script` to transform the data during the migration or filter out certain documents. Or it might perform an "Update all" operation that runs a script on a set of docs to update some part of them.

### Release notes

Adding features to Advanced Search would often require a manual reindex to be able to immediately use the new feature.

Now when we add new features, reindexing will happen in the background without manual intervention. Reindexing can still be performed manually when needed.

https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/elasticsearch.html#creating-a-new-global-search-migration

title: Report combined AMAU for Git write operations via usage ping
description:
### Problem to solve

The AMAU counters added by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219956 are separated by repository type (project, wiki, design), but the total distinct users is somewhere between the maximum and sum of these values. This means we are currently under or over counting Create SMAU for self hosted instances.

On GitLab.com this is not a problem because we can calculate it directly from the database dump.

### Proposal

Add a new field that takes the distinct count of all users who performed any Git write operation to the `usage_activity_by_stage_monthly` section of the usage ping.

### Links / references

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219956

title: Visual Review Tools Docs improvements
description:

The Documentation for [Visual Review Tools](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/review_apps/#visual-reviews-starter) is missing some things that would make using this feature easier and add context.

1. What problem does this solve for the user?
1. How does this feature work?
   - What are the prerequisites for using it?
   - Example project that walks through setup
   - clarify why MR ID would be wanted / needed and how to set it up through an environment variable

-->

title: Remove known fields from trial sign up form
description:
### Hypothesis 

We can improve the trial signup rate by reducing the cognitive load on the page
 
### Potential experiment
Pulling from the [UX trial scorecard](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/growth/-/epics/7#step-personalise-the-form), we could test hiding any form fields where we already know the value. 
 
For example, I have a test account where I signed up with the first name `Sam` last name `test`, in this example the form would hide the first and last name fields and start at the Company name question. 
 
![image](/uploads/03c86288bc8d9d8c25699e7a5ba53c53/image.png)
  
* Users in the control would still see the first, last name fields under all conditions 
* Users in the experiment would have the first, last name fields hidden if we already have values for these fields
* We will measure the success of the experiment by understanding if users in the experiment group where the fields are hidden have a higher conversion rate on the form than users in the control where the values are also known
 
**Note:** We should check if we have known information for any fields on the trial form and hide the fields where we have known information. For example, some users in this test https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/251230 will be providing company information at signup so we should hide these questions if these users were to attempt to start a trial in the future. The goal is that over time as users give us more information the number of required fields to start a trial keeps getting reduced. 
 
### Experiment tracking 
 
* Track user_ids of users in the control and experiment groups 
* Users in the control should have known values in first, last name fields
* Users in the experiment group should have values in the first, last name fields
* For both the experiment and control groups track the unique views and the unique submissions of the form

title: Remove secrets-sast from the SAST vendored template
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve
Now that Secret Detection has it's own vendored template and section within SAST I think the old job should be removed so that folks don't see two secret detection jobs when they include `SAST` and `Secret-Detection` in their `.gitlab-ci.yml`s. 
<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->


### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 
Remove confusion on which secrets-detection job to run. Remove risk of allowing two secret-detection jobs from being kicked off.

### Proposal
Remove [secrets-sast](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/SAST.gitlab-ci.yml#L171-179 ) from the sast vendored template. Remove variable documentation pinned to the old version of secrets (v2) in this [SAST documentation page](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/#vulnerability-filters). 

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

title: Add description from release post content into GitLab-org releases page
description:
### Problem to solve

We implemented a fantastic view of the about.gitlab.com releases page inside of GitLab by using the Releases feature functionality. Users are interested in no longer being dependent on the Release Post to populate the Releases pages.

### Intended users

* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager)
* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* All internal GitLab Users

### User experience goal

As a user, I want to be able to see a brief description of the feature right on the releases page without having to go to documentation 

### Proposal 

- Add the description keyword attribute from the release post to be pulled into the GitLab.org page 
- Synchronize `description` field from the feature YAML. e.g. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/blob/master/data/release_posts/13_1/phikai-webide-core-features.yml#L12
- Make sure the `description` is visible in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases (mirror page).
- If necessary, adjust the page style (GFM).

#### Future implications 

- We may want to consider what ever header we use to stay the same from how this gets pulled into the release notes section of the release page 
- We will also need to consider a character limit and images if people want those to be included

title: Persist the JWT to prevent having to regularly authenticate when using the Conan Repository
description:
### Problem to solve
When using the Conan Repository, the personal access token is not stored locally. Conan uses JWT, so when you run commands, Conan will request an expirable token from GitLab using your token. The JWT does expire on a regular basis, so you will need to re-enter your personal access token when that happens.


### Intended users
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal
As a user, I don't have to keep logging into Conan, which is problematic when using CI.
<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses?

https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 


### Proposal
Persist the JWT for Conan so that users do not have to keep logging in every <n> minutes.

title: Improve UX for applying dropdown selections
description:
### Problem(s)

During recent testing sessions with users for the [category maturity scorecard Lovability of Issue Tracking](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/issues/7209), many users struggled with understanding how to apply items selected in the Assignee dropdown. The solution currently is to make the selections, then click outside of the dropdown and it applies the changes, but it created friction in the user's experience and therefore the feature was given a lower score in terms of ease of use. This seems to be the case in any search-related dropdown which has the option for multiple selections.

At least one user also expressed confusion over why there were seemingly 2 search fields when the assignee list was expanded.

### Proposals 

UPDATE DROPDOWNS IN PAJAMAS TO REFLECT THIS PROPOSAL....
* Functionality is as it currently is, but "Edit" on the right changes to an "Apply" button which technically just closes (and applies) the changes. [See prototype here.](https://www.figma.com/proto/SJWRMhjIYOt8pTLpygN6HE/233978-Improve-UX-for-Dropdowns?node-id=1%3A3&viewport=361%2C561%2C0.5888686776161194&scaling=min-zoom) -- 

**Notice that this prototype removes the following:** 

![Screen_Shot_2020-09-08_at_9.07.59_AM](/uploads/7a2e7ddc9f8d6d29d0c8b12d6b1f97fb/Screen_Shot_2020-09-08_at_9.07.59_AM.png)

which results in a single `search` input. 

I believe the third option would be simplest for MVC right now. If the removal of the upper dropdown input is too much, even just swapping the Edit to Apply could simplify the experience a bit more by providing feedback that the system is ready for the user to act.
