title: Improve UX for adding related items
description:
### Problem
During recent testing sessions with users for the [category maturity scorecard Lovability of Issue Tracking](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/issues/7209), one of the most common interaction challenges was applying linked/related items to an issue. In most cases, when users were attempting to add one issue to another as related or blocked, they would enter the ID number only (without the hashtag), which resulted in an error. They often did not read the placeholder text. In another case, they wanted to enter the title of the issue.

These challenges resulted sometimes in the user not being able to complete the scenario at all, or completing them after a time but giving the task a low score for ease of use and meeting requirements.

There are other design opportunities for Related items such as layout and flow that could be addressed in separate issues, but this issue focuses on the primary interaction problem which was surrounding the users frequently not entering the hashtag and how to simplify that process for them.

### Proposals

- We can currently search by issue number if you first input `#`. The basic idea would be for the FE to automatically append the `#` to any issue number...so If i type `#` followed by `12` we would autocomplete based on issue number. If I just start typing `12`, we append `#` to the beginning of the string being passed in to the search it will still autocomplete based by issue number without the user having to remember to first add `#`. 

Other ideas:
<details>
* Option 1: Improve smart search to detect issue number with or without # for related items. Considerations will need to be made regarding how this affects other related items such as related MRs to issues and issues/sub-epics to epics. In that case, showing results as groups, segmented by object type seems like a good first step. Longer term, having a [single customizable widget](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229731) may be the better approach.
* Option 2: Attach a hashtag by default for linked issues as an uneditable piece (separate input I assume) if we're only going to allow one object association to another for the time being. This would automatically apply the element so the user doesn't have to type it in. Epics allows either associating epics to issues or other epics, but it's still a prescribed path currently. Eventually, could provide a dropdown for this so the user can select the character associated with the object type. [See proposal here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233975/designs/Paper.Project.22.png).
</details>

## Availability and Testing

Ensure test coverage in unit/integration tests. Manual job `package-and-qa` will need to be run in the MR.

title: Promote an Issue to an Epic via the UI
description:
### Problem
In recent testing with users for the issue tracking category maturity scorecard assessment, nearly all struggled with the task of promoting an issue to an epic. It's currently a quick action only and users had trouble discovering the feature, even when given access to help resources and Google.

Users also continuously navigated to the "Close Issue" dropdown at the top of the page, searching for items that allow them to "manage" it.

### Final Proposal   
Creating an ellipsis menu to replace the "New issue" button and moving "New issue", "Promote to epic" and "Report" into this menu. The divider lines exist between these items because they serve separate purposes and will help to visually separate/group related items as the menu is built upon over time.  
![Issue_List_-_MVC](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/2c49772e54fc206b12a3053d70260a05/Issue_List_-_MVC.png)


### Proposals
* Option 1 (**PM likes this one**): Surface Promote to Epic in the UI through a [combined menu option - see example](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233974/designs/Paper.Project.23.png). I proposed including "Move issue" here as well. Reference also may make sense here. But those elements I believe are more related to general issue management rather than attributes of an issue. "Move issue" could be a concept that may need to be bumped to a separate discussion, but combining these like elements could not only clean up the right sidebar, but make both features a bit more discoverable and reduce the user's cognitive load in having multiple ways to manage an issue. The "To Do" option could potentially also go here.
* Option 2: Add "Promote" to sidebar. In this case, we'd keep "Move issue" in the bar, but add Promote.[ See examples](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233974/designs/Paper.Project.24.png).


### MVCs

- [ ] Move existing `Move`, `New issue`, and `Report abuse` into combined list drop down
- [ ] Add `Promote to epic` to list drop down
- [ ] Keep `Close issue` to the left of the ellipsis. Leave color as it is currently (we'll update it in another issue)
- [ ] Figure out UX for adding Move to the drop down given the user will need to be able to specify the target project the issue is to be moved to.

### Feature flag

The ellipsis dropdown menu, and `Promote to epic dropdown item`, is behind the feature flag `:vue_issue_header`. This flag applies to the frontend and is defaulted to off.

### Release Notes

Description: Promoting an Issue to an Epic is not an intuitive process as you have to use a [Quick Action](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/quick_actions.html) when editing an Issue description or making a comment. To make this action more discoverable, we've introduced a new secondary actions menu in the Issue header and added a button to quickly promote an Issue to an Epic with a single click. 

Documentation: TBD

title: Display more columns in Merge Request Analytics data table [BE]
description:
### Problem to solve

Some desirable columns were not added in the [Merge Request Analytics data table MVC](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229365) because they "need extra queries (preloading) since they are not aggregated ... if we want to be able to sort by these columns, we'll need to think about storing the counts somewhere." ([source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229365#note_386850022))

### Proposal

In the Merge Request Analytics data table, add the following columns:

- [ ] Comments (Needs a preloader query)
- [x] Commits (Needs to be exposed from MR metrics)
- [ ] Approvals (Needs a preloader query)
- [x] Pipelines (with a check if the MR passed CI when merged) - (not sure but we might need a preloader query for this info)

We already have this data in our DB, however it's not available via the GraphQL API.

title: Pipelines email service API returns `"true"` instead of `true`
description:
### Summary

The GET [pipeline-emails API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/services.html#get-pipeline-emails-service-settings) returns the string `"true"` instead of `true` for the `notify_only_broken_pipelines` field.

### Steps to reproduce

Create a pipelines emails integration for a project **in the UI**, and run:
```
curl API_URL/projects/PROJECT/services/pipelines-email?private_token=TOKEN
```


### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/jeremad/test

```
curl https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/19032531/services/pipelines-email?private_token=...
```

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The API returns:
```
{...,
  "properties": {
    "recipients": "...",
    "notify_only_broken_pipelines": "true",
    "branches_to_be_notified": "default"
  }
}
```

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
The API should return:

```
{...,
  "properties": {
    "recipients": "...",
    "notify_only_broken_pipelines": true,
    "branches_to_be_notified": "default"
  }
}
```

### Possible resolution

After a brief look at the code, it seems all services integration are affected

description:

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

When navigating the MR Diffs using File by File navigation, the previous and next buttons always use the same order (list view). If the File Tree is rendering in Tree view mode, in some situations the order is not what is expected (because it's following the List mode).

### Steps to reproduce

1. Enable file by file mode in https://gitlab.com/profile/preferences
1. Go to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/31610/diffs
1. Ensure you are in Tree View mode
1. Scroll down to the file: `definition_spec.rb`
1. Push "next", below the diff file
1. See that you didn't jump to `use_rugged_spec.rb`, as would be expected.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/31610/diffs

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

It always follows the list view order.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

It respects the order being shown on the file sidebar on the left. (even though this could be hidden from sight)

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Kapture_2020-08-06_at_12.21.25](/uploads/590f2e1fe179496ccb0f4ddde9fc6454/Kapture_2020-08-06_at_12.21.25.mp4)

title: Dependency Scanning doesn't support NodeJs project using Yarn v2
description:
### Summary Dependency Scanning reports no dependencies for a Node JS project using [Yarn v2](https://yarnpkg.com/) is used. NOTE: This is a multi-project repo that also contains Python code. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Have a repo that contains Node JS code. 2. Dependencies are managed through [Yarn v2](https://yarnpkg.com/) for Node 3. Run a pipeline that contains the Dependency Scanning job. 4. The Node JS dependencies aren't listed in the Dependency List. ### Example Project Repo Structure ```shell ├── README.md ├── amplify.yml ├── commitlint.config.js ├── docs │ └── YSLY.png ├── package.json ├── packages │ ├── backend | | └── package.json │ ├── shared | | └── package.json │ ├── types | | └── package.json │ └── webapp | | └── package.json ├── scripts │ └── exportCognitoUsers | | └── requirements.txt └── tsconfig.json ``` If needed access can be given to the project where the bug is encountered. ### What is the current *bug* behavior? The Yarn dependencies neither listed nor scanned. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? All dependencies are listed and scanned, included the ones managed by Yarn v2. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

title: Follow-up from "Wire up GraphQL query to dynamic form"
description:
The following discussions from !38318 should be addressed:

- [ ] @markrian started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38318#note_389785033):  (+3 comments)

    > @beckalippert Would you review some pieces of the UX here, please? In particular:
    > 
    > - I've updated the SAST Configuration UI's subheading text to comply with the [latest designs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/228830), although I'm not 100% sure about the wording.
    > - I added an error state in the case the configuration data couldn't be loaded (this is a non-user-recoverable problem). The alert shown is non-dismissible. I'm not sure on the wording here, either :sweat_smile: 
    > - The `Loaded` screenshot in the description doesn't quite align with the designs - particularly, the input sizes are wrong and the default value isn't being set correctly. These will be fixed by additional ~backend changes in another MR.
    > 
    > Thanks!

- [ ] @markrian started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38318#note_389785623):  (+1 comment)

    > Do we want to use abbreviations like `docs` in the UI? cc @beckalippert

- [ ] @markrian started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38318#note_389786285):  (+2 comments)

    > This error message would only be shown if something has gone badly wrong (e.g., the backend is down, or the user's connection is down). Is suggesting that they reload the page the right advice? cc @beckalippert

## Implementation plan

- [x] Apply change described in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38318#note_390966711
- [x] Apply change described in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233910#note_392199031

title: Issues Analytics: Add closed issues to table
description:
### Problem to solve

- Issues analytics only shows opened issues - this information isn't too valuable by itself.
- Related to [Q3 Dogfooding OKR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/issues/8303)

title: Enable single file review mode from the MR Changes tab
description: ### Problem to solve The recently shipped feature of reviewing File by file in MRs https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35223 is buried in the User preferences (https://gitlab.com/profile/preferences). Users should be able to toggle it on and off from the MR page itself. ### Intended users All users of MRs. ### User experience goal Easily toggle on and off the preference. ### Proposal ### Further details While we have the feature flag, this needs to be tied to the same feature flag. Another detail: * What should we do with the User preference in the settings? Keep these two places always in sync? Or remove it from the user settings? ### Documentation An update to this section is in order: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/reviewing_and_managing_merge_requests.html#file-by-file-diff-navigation ### Availability & Testing ### What does success look like, and how can we measure that? ### Links / references See Epic for related work: https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/516 ### Release Notes Using [single-file diff mode](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/reviewing_and_managing_merge_requests.html#file-by-file-diff-navigation) is useful to improve performance and navigation of large merge requests, however, enabling it previously meant leaving the merge request, going into user preferences, and enabling the option. This releases introduces the capability to enable single-diff mode right within the merge request view. As you navigate to the "changes" tab of the merge request, simply click the gear icon and check the box labeled `Display one file at a time`. This will display a single file at a time and enable the `prev` and `next` buttons to navigate among files.

title: Tail or cat or add a message if compilation fails
description:
Sometimes we are piping outputs of commands into files. If you do not know that, it is really hard to go see what is going on, e.g.: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/673545511. As far as I understand we do that to keep the logs more readable and smaller (storage?)


```
$ run_timed_command "bin/rake gitlab:assets:compile > assets-compile.log 2>&1"
$ bin/rake gitlab:assets:compile > assets-compile.log 2>&1
Uploading artifacts for failed job
00:17
Uploading artifacts...
assets-compile.log: found 1 matching files and directories 
public/assets/: found 834 matching files and directories 
node_modules/@gitlab/svgs/dist/icons.json: found 1 matching files and directories 
Uploading artifacts as "archive" to coordinator... ok  id=673545511 responseStatus=201 Created token=hDzSRq3o
ERROR: Job failed: exit code 1
```

I think it would be helpful if we either:

1. `cat` the log
2. `tail` the log + echo a message that the log can be found in the artifacts. We probably can even build the url to the artifacts page for convience. So for example the log above could have looks like this:

```
$ run_timed_command "bin/rake gitlab:assets:compile > assets-compile.log 2>&1"
$ bin/rake gitlab:assets:compile > assets-compile.log 2>&1

Error: You have unmet dependencies. (`yarn check` command failed)
Run `yarn install` to install missing modules.
   
For the full log go to: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/673545511/artifacts/browse

00:17
```

title: Delete stopped environments automatically
description:
## Description

This is continuation from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/19724. Today, we have a performance issue that stopped environments **still retain [deployment refs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#check-out-deployments-locally)**. This cause [performance degradation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/-/issues/56466#note_132597317). In fact, customers [also face this issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/19724#note_372832148). Another example => https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223155

We should **delete** unnecessary environments in order to speed up git operation. This brings a lot of benefits to entire GtiLab features, especially GitLab-Runners that the total amount of refs they need to fetch will be significantly reduced.

## Proposal

Delete stopped environments automatically.

**Which environments will be deleted?**

- The environment has already been **stopped** for more than a month.
- The environment [is not protected](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/protected_environments.html).

This should also cover https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225794.

## Example

Given you have the following .gitlab-ci.yml:

```yaml
review:
  environment:
    name: review/$CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME
    auto_stop_in: 1 week

production:
  environment: production
```

The outcome is:

- If the `review/something` environment is running for a week, it'll be **stopped** by [environment auto-stop feature](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#environments-auto-stop) feature.
- If the `review/something` environment has been stopped for a month, it'll be **deleted** by the new feature.
- The `production` environment will never be stopped automatically.
- If the `production` environment has been stopped by manual operation, it **won't** be deleted because the environment was not stopped by [environment auto-stop feature](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#environments-auto-stop) feature.

title: Design: Auto-resolve vulnerabilities when no longer detected
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

When a security vulnerability was previously detected but is no longer found in a subsequent scan, the status of the vulnerability will remain unchanged. This forces an individual to have to manually set the status to "Resolved" in order to accurately describe the status of the vulnerability. 

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

A [scan result security policy](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/6237) at the project/group/instance level that gives GitLab the permission to automatically resolve security vulnerabilities when they are no longer being detected in subsequent scans. This can be further broken down to allow selecting specific scanners to allow automatic resolution. That way, teams can decide more granularly which removed vulnerabilities need a person to review before closing versus which ones can be trusted to the automation.

**Note**: The previous solution of a setting has been replaced with a [new policy-based approach](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233846#note_717504640).

### Further Details

For Product companies like GitLab, it makes sense to keep track of vulnerabilities over time. One version could have been shipped with a critical vulnerability, which means a new security release even though the security issue has been remediated since.  
For SaaS companies, the workflow is different. With Continuous Delivery, the state of the service is often the state of the latest pipeline in `master` (or any other main branch). In this case, the users don't really care about what occurred in the past.  
They would probably use more [notifications](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/4905) in this case than this dashboard.

### Requirements

## Requirements 

- The auto-resolved vulnerability should have an activity item stating that it was resolved because of X policy (and ideally, a link to the policy).

epic.title: Auto-resolve vulnerabilities when not found in subsequent scans

title: Importing Groups from an export is not importing sub-children
description:
### Summary Importing Groups from an export didn't import sub-children. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create a Group/Sub group structure like below: ```mermaid graph LR root[Group A] --> 1[Group B] root --> 2[Group C] root --> 3[Group D] 3 --> 31[Group D1] 3 --> 32[Group D2] 2 --> 21[Group C1] 2 --> 22[Group C2] linkStyle 0,1,2,3,4,5,6 stroke-width:1px; ``` 2. Export the Group. 3. After the export process is complete, attempt to import the Group. 4. The imported group should have the same structure, but Groups C1, C2 and D1, D2 are missing. ### Example Project (If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report) (If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version) ### What is the current *bug* behavior? The imported group should have the same structure, but Groups C1, C2 and D1, D2 are missing. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? The imported group should have the same structure, but Groups C1, C2 and D1, D2 are missing. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots (Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code as it's tough to read otherwise.) ### Output of checks (If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com) #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes (If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem)

title: Add Analytics area to admin panel
description:
## Problem to solve
We've previously introduced the [instance statistics](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/instance_statistics/) area in the top navbar. This icon is configurable to be publicly available or only available to admins.

We'd like to move away from a dedicated area for instance-level statistics: at the moment, it only has 2 features (Cohorts and DevOps Score) and looks neglected. The icon also looks a little out of place in the top navbar and can be improved.

Our plan is to design another place for instance-level things in our navigation, and open up instance-level analytics features to everyone on the instance. Until then, we should move instance-level analytics features to the admin panel so we can iterate on them more quickly for admins.

## Proposal
Introduce an Analytics area in the admin panel, as the second item in the sidebar (between Overview and Monitoring).

![Screen_Shot_2020-08-18_at_5.48.54_PM](/uploads/9f7d0f7a4195a5db5d4549727fbc633d/Screen_Shot_2020-08-18_at_5.48.54_PM.png)

Remove the option to toggle "instance statistics" in `Admin > Settings > Metrics and profiling > Usage statistics`. Make the relevant views only viewable by an admin.

title: Update self-managed labels to `Billable Users`
description:
## Summary

Many users and internal team members, believe that a level of activity is factored into whether a user is considered billable, this is not the case. All users created on the instance regardless of the amount of times they've logged in, whether they are associated with projects or groups or if they've accessed the system at all are considered eligible for billing.

I'd like to change all labels which currently denote the number of users which occupy a seat in the license as `Billable Users` to remove the confusion related to `Active`. 

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233820 for the various ways we currently represent billable users.

### Actions

1. [ ] Replace `Active Users` located Admin>Overview>Dashboard
1. [ ] Replace `Active users (Billable users)` located Admin>Overview>Dashboard>Users statistics
1. [ ] Replace `Active Users` located Admin>License

title: Remove confusing text on vulnerability finding modal
description:
On the modal for vulnerabilities is a link for "Learn More about interacting with security reports" and it links the user to https://gitlab.com/help/user/application_security/index#solutions-for-vulnerabilities-auto-remediation

This text should either be removed completely as it does not make sense on most screens, or it should only be there conditionally when there is an auto-remediation.

## Implementation plan

- The file responsible for showing this message is `ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/security_reports/components/solution_card.vue`. The related `showLearnAboutRemedationMsg` computed property and the `a` element in the file which displays the text should be removed.
